name: Sacha Lodge

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We came here for the second half of our honeymoon in Ecuador (the first half was in the Galapagos) and could not have been more pleased! My husband is a vegan and we were worried about the food. We booked through Adventure Life who assured us that it would not be an issue but given the remote location, we were a little skeptical. The box lunches we received before the river trip to the lodge did not include a vegan lunch so we were starting to get worried. We needn't have worried! During our stay there, the cooking staff went out of their way to prepare plentiful, delicious, creative, and beautiful meals for my husband. In fact, there were a few occasions when our dining companions were a little envious when his meals would arrive at the table! Our guide Sebastien was amazing and truly knowledgeable about the wildlife. He also had eagle eyes and would always somehow spot the birds, mammals, and reptiles and amphibians that were initially hidden from our eyes. Our indigenous guide also shared wonderful insights into his culture and their relationship with the environment. The accommodations are rustic and while there are screens on the windows, the rooms are by no means impervious to insects. Expect nightly visitors in your rooms! Also definitely use the dry box! I left a book out for a few hours and the papers had completely curled by the time I returned to the room! The service by the rest of the staff was above and beyond. We decided to try to fish (feed) the piranha in the lake and the staff cheerfully provided some old meat to use as bait. I was worried about mosquitoes but it was not buggy around the lodge at all (although I was stung by a wasp randomly while drinking coffee and minding my own business - ouch!). The forest is of course another matter and you definitely need bug spray. One last word: I am terrified of heights and went on the canopy walk anyway. At one point, I simply could not take the rope bridge to the next observation tower. The rest of the group went on and I remained behind. After a few minutes, our guide returned and tried to coax me across. I initially refused but he patiently walked ahead of me and ordered me to just focus on his shoes and grip the handrail. He even told me he was initially afraid of the canopy walk when he first started working there to make me feel better (even though I'm pretty he just made that up!) I was petrified but once I got across, I was so happy to be there (we saw some great wildlife)! I was even able to go back across the bridge after we finished, to the other tower so we could make our way down. I was glad I did it so even if you're afraid of heights I would recommend you try it anyway (at least if your guide is Sebastien)!
reviews.title: Perfect end to honeymoon (with a vegan)

reviews.text: Four of us went to Sacha Lodge for a 4 day stay. The rooms were basic but clean and we were surprised to find power 24/7. The food was amazingly good, considering everything must be transported to the lodge. And, the insects were minimal; we are bothered more in Flordia.
reviews.title: Unexpected comfort and service in the Amazon.
Beware of "Guides" in the Amazon Basin Lodges in Ecuador
reviews.text: Our tour guide (Gus) was very knowledgable and patient with all of our questions. Our native guide (Gerardo) could spot wild life that we would have never noticed. His stories of living in the Ecuadoran rain forest were interesting and revealed a dying way of life. They both worked hard to show us what we were interested in seeing and always courteous. The both were ambassadors for preservation of the rain forsest.
We would encourage anyone to take this trip. Tropical Tours arranged our tours in Quito and the guides, Jose and Javier, shared history and local customs in a very interesting way.
reviews.title: It Just Doesn't Get Better Than This!

reviews.text: I had a wonderful stay in April 2011 at the Sacha Lodge on the Napo River in Ecuador. However, guides, which are compulsory in most places it seems, can be greedy, rapacious, and largely unappreciate of the tips that you are supposed to be giving them. I wasn't fully aware of the tip policy in both the Galapagos Islands and the Amazon Rainforest, but I sure am now! We each tipped $5 a day, which is what I was told, and both myself and my group were severely rebuffed by a guide named "Marcos" a.k.a. Cachi, a native guide who spoke English, because he didn't think our tip was sufficient and confronted one of the people in my group. In fact, he treated us horribly for the remainder of the trip. Watch our for tipping in Ecuador and especially ungrateful guides.
reviews.title: Tons of fun

reviews.text: Sacha Lodge is on a lagoon near the Napo River, a major tributary of the Amazon. We knew we were in good hands from the moment we arrived at Quito airport for the 30 minute flight to Coca. A Lodge representative took details of our activity preferences and ushered us through check-in with tickets, tags and boarding passes. Similarly, at Coca we were met, transferred to their Coca house, given lunch then walked to to motorised canoe for the 2 hour trip to the Lodge.
reviews.title: Runs like Swiss clockwork but with charm and personality

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The Lodge is attractively situated on a lagoon, populated with caiman and pirahnas and with duplex cabins a distance away on boardwalks. On each of the four days we were there we arose and breakfasted early and were out on the morning expedition from 7 to 11 with a second expedition in the late afternoon. We had an excellent guide, Jarol, and a local native guide each day just for the four of us. The excursions were, at our request, heavily orientated towards bird watching but with plenty of opportunities to observe all aspects of the evironment. In the middle of the day a swim in the lagoon (yes, with the caimans and pirahnas) was very refreshing.
reviews.title: The ideal way to experience the jungle

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: All the meals were buffet, largely European in style, with a huge range of choices - all excellent quality. The barbecue night on the jetty over the lake was a highlight.
reviews.title: You have to have a rainforest experience at least once in lifetime!
Paradise on earth
reviews.text: The speedy laundry service, in by breakfast, back by 11am was a great boon in that humid environment.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Sacha Lodge is a big operation that runs like clockwork but with the workings invisible to the guests. We felt well looked after at all times.
reviews.title: A great chance to see what the Amazon basin has to offer in Ecuador

reviews.text: Can only reiterate the comments of those above. I was impressed by the smooth and unobtrusive service standard, the fabulous food and most of all by the two guides looking after our group, Efrain and Sergio. I didn't ask Efrain's surname but cannot believe he is the same one mentioned unfavorably in a previous review: this Efrain could not have gone to more trouble to make our treks a success and was good company, friendly and knowledgeable throughout. Special thanks to Sergio for his first spot of a dozing sloth which was a highlight! And for the almost silent paddling of our group up and down the rivers, especially the Anaconda river at dusk which was magical. Overall, splendid!
reviews.title: Lifetime dream fulfilled in every way

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We enjoyed a 4 day/3 night package in August.
reviews.title: Go there!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: As stated in reviews by other travellers, you are well taken care of from the time you arrive at the airport in Quito, and until you are checked in at the airport in Coca when departing. The trip down the Rio Napo is an adventure in itself.
reviews.title: Wonderful Experience

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: You will be divided into small groups with which you eat all your meals. We were matched up with a very polite and nice couple on the same age as us, and we were able to enjoy each others company. (It shall be said that the average age is somewhat higher than ours - early 30.)
reviews.title: A Birdwatcher's Heaven And A Rainforest and Jungle Experience

reviews.text: We were appointed with a naturalist and a native guide. The naturalist, David, who freelanced for Sacha, showed both sincere knowledge and enthusiasm for his work. Our native guide, Panchito, provided innumerable useful anecdotes on how the flora were used by the natives. We specially enjoyed the Kapok watch tower and the canopy walk.
reviews.title: Great Introduction to the Amazon

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We just returned from a 5-day/4-night stay at Sacha Lodge, and there simply aren't enough good things to say about it. I could write a couple of pages about the trip, but will content myself with basic information.
reviews.title: Ab-fab rain forest lodge

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: First and foremost, the efficiency of this entire operation is amazing. From start to finish, everything was done as advertised. The booking process was simple, and e-mails were answered immediately if not sooner. Unless you bring your own larger group, you'll be placed into a small group of no more than 6 people with shared interests, and you'll not catch sight of any other groups while you're on your "expeditions". You have both a naturalist guide and a native guide, both of whom are experts on the area you're visiting.
reviews.title: Absolutely delightful!

reviews.text: The staff is incredible! There's always someone handy to answer a question, give directions, or assist in any way you ask....it seems nothing is too much trouble. Many of them speak a little English, and they're all courteous to a fault.
reviews.title: Dont believe the negative review about Ephrain Lopez. Total Rubbish

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The lodgings are all one could ask for in the rain forest. Our cabin was native wood with large screened windows, excellent ventilation, a fabulous ceiling fan, a modern bathroom with shower (never a lack of hot water, and excellent water pressure), and a private porch furnished with comfy hand-made wooden chairs and a hammock. Our windows and porch looked out into the forest, where we watched monkeys travel past to and from feeding areas. The beds were extremely comfy and, combined with the night sounds of the forest and, occasionally, rain on the roof, dozing off took about 5 minutes. The cabins are spotlessly clean, and kept that way on a daily basis by the two staffers who, miraculously, make everything neat and clean while you're on your morning expedition.
reviews.title: Amazing Surprise in the Amazon!!!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Our guides were Daniel, from the UK, and Jaime, from the Tena area. Daniel planned our twice-daily expeditions and frequently gave us a choice of activities. We walked in the forest learning about plants and trees, spotted wildlife from tiny poison dart frogs to monkeys and toucans, and, from Jaime, learned how to weave thatch and use several medicinal plants. They rowed the canoe when we went on the lake and through the canals, while we were free to use our cameras and binoculars to best advantage. It was just the luck of the draw that we got these two gents, and we feel extremely lucky that we did...they're the best!
reviews.title: Amazon at it's finest

description: -300 mts Long canopy walk.-45 mts wooden tower a round a kepok tree.-Buterfly Farm.-Visit to the yasuni parrot leak.-On the leake BBq dinning area.-Bird watching guides.-Bilingual guides English-French-German.
